p17_p17443228_s52412008.IMPRESSION: The second of two views of the chest shows the ET tube still at the carina, 3.5 cm below optimal placement. Lung volumes are lower and mild pulmonary edema is new.  Consolidation in the left lower lobe is probably a combination of edema and atelectasis, but needs to be followed to exclude aspiration pneumonia, particularly given the history of hematemesis. What is most striking is the severe acute distension of mediastinal veins, most prominently the azygos, in the right tracheobronchial angle.  The azygos was already mildly dilated earlier in the day, but not in ___, so it is not a congenital finding. Therefore causes of acute azygos distention should be reviewed clinically, including cirrhosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, inferior vena cava thrombosis, right heart failure, and less likely because of pulmonary edema, cardiac tamponade due to pericardial effusion.
